AudioEncoder.summary: The AudioEncoder interface of the WebCodecs API encodes objects.

AudioEncoderEncodeQueueSize.summary: The encodeQueueSize read-only property of the interface returns the number of pending encode requests in the queue.
AudioEncoderEncodeQueueSize.value: An integer containing the number of requests.

AudioEncoderAudioEncoder.summary: The AudioEncoder() constructor creates a new object with the provided init.output callback assigned as the output callback, the provided init.error callback as the error callback, and the set to "unconfigured".

AudioEncoderIsConfigSupported.summary: The isConfigSupported() static method of the interface checks if the given config is supported (that is, if objects can be successfully configured with the given config).
AudioEncoderIsConfigSupported.returns: A that resolves with an object containing the following members:

AudioEncoderFlush.summary: The flush() method of the interface returns a Promise that resolves once all pending messages in the queue have been completed.

AudioEncoderEncode.summary: The encode() method of the interface enqueues a control message to encode a given object.

AudioEncoderConfigure.summary: The configure() method of the interface enqueues a control message to configure the audio encoder for encoding chunks.

AudioEncoderState.summary: The state read-only property of the interface returns the current state of the underlying codec.
AudioEncoderState.value: A string containing one of the following values:

AudioEncoderDequeue.summary: The dequeue event of the interface fires to signal a decrease in .

remarks.para: This eliminates the need for developers to use a poll to determine when the queue has decreased, and more work should be queued up.

AudioEncoderClose.summary: The close() method of the interface ends all pending work and releases system resources.

AudioEncoderReset.summary: The reset() method of the interface resets all states including configuration, control messages in the control message queue, and all pending callbacks.
